question: 1 (j)
sols_html:
In this case we need to use logarithmic differentiation, indeed it is impossible to use the power rule since there is an \(x^2\) as exponent. We cannot differentiate it in the same way we do for exponential functions since we take the power of x and not e or another constant. Hence we need to use logarithmic differentiation. First set

\[\begin{aligned} y=x^{(x^2)},\end{aligned}\]

then taking the logarithm on both sides we find

\[\begin{aligned} \ln y = \ln (x^{(x^2)}) = x^2 \ln(x).\end{aligned}\]

Now keeping in mind that y is a function of x, we can take the derivatives on both sides and get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{d}{dx} (x^2 \ln(x)) .\end{aligned}\]

The left-hand side is simply

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx} \ln y = \frac{1}{y} \cdot \frac{d}{dx} y = \frac{1}{y} y',\end{aligned}\]

while the right-hand side gives, using the product rule,

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}(x^2 \ln(x)) = 2x \ln(x) + x^2 \frac{1}{x} = 2x \ln(x) + x.\end{aligned}\]

Putting everything back together, we get

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{1}{y} y' = 2x \ln(x) + x,\end{aligned}\]

and thus

\[\begin{aligned} \displaystyle y' = y (2x \ln(x) + x).\end{aligned}\]

Replacing y by \(x^{(x^2)},\) we finally get

\[\begin{aligned} y' = x^{(x^2)} ( 2x \ln(x) + x).\end{aligned}\]
